title: Run node command in NWJS
body:
Hi,
I would like to know if there is a way to run node command using the `nwjs.exe` file?

In the local PC with installed Node.JS we can use the node command to run a js file as follows.
Ex: `node index.js`

If this is not possible in NWJS application, I would like to request this as a feature in the environment so that the aforementioned commands can be run.

Thank you.
author: ishanuda

comments.body:
It sounds like what you want is a portable version of Node.js, which already exists (you'll have to google it) and will be a much smaller footprint than something that ships an entire browser.

If you want to use a Node script as the entry point for your application, that is possible with NW.js, by setting it in the `main` of your `package.json` to `file.js`. Alternatively, you can use `node-main` to run a script prior to your `main` window launching. This is often used to spin up a web server prior to the window opening.

In your application, if you want to import or run Node.js files, you can use `require('./file.js')` at any point.

hi,
Thank you very much for the information.

title: Packaging recommendations no longer active
body:
NWJS Version : latest
Operating System : all

### Expected behavior

Documentation refers to active projects for packaging and distribution.

### Actual behavior

nw.js/docs/For Users/Package and Distribute.md 

Recommended:  nwjs-builder-phoenix (archived by developer)
Also mentions: nw-builder (over 2 years since last commit)

Lack of maintenance on these projects will make them poorer and poorer choices as vulnerabilities in dependencies go unpatched etc...

Forking the recommended builder project and bringing it under the nwjs project banner seems like a sensible approach.

title: process exit event isn't alway fired.
author: lili21

comments.body: Maybe you can try the SIGTERM or SIGKILL events.

I ran into this issue today as well when I noticed that my application was not terminating any spawned child processes on application exit and all these spawned processes were being stacked up on each additional app launch.

I'm only able to reproduce this issue when calling `require("nw.gui").App.quit()` though.
When calling `require("nw.gui").Window.get().close(true)` or `process.exit()`, all process exit related listeners are working correctly and a cleanup of all child processes is possible.

Tested with `0.21.6` and `0.25.3` on Linux x64.
I think this bug deserves some attention. Thanks!
